title: Rectangles
statementHtml:
You are given a binary grid∗∗ GG of dimensions n×mn×m.

Let us define a rectangle as a tuple (u,d,l,r)(u,d,l,r) that satisfies the following conditions:

Then, the area of a rectangle (u,d,l,r)(u,d,l,r) is defined as (d−u+1)⋅(r−l+1)(d−u+1)⋅(r−l+1).

For example, consider the following binary grid given below.

101011010000101

110000111000101

Here, you may see two rectangles (1,2,1,3)(1,2,1,3) and (1,3,3,5)(1,3,3,5)††, each of which has area 66 and 99, respectively.

For each cell (i,j)(i,j), find the minimum area of any rectangle (u,d,l,r)(u,d,l,r) such that u≤i≤du≤i≤d and l≤j≤rl≤j≤r.

∗∗A binary grid is a grid where each cell contains 00 or 11. The cell on the jj-th column of the ii-th row is denoted as cell (i,j)(i,j).

††Note that these are the only rectangles in the grid; for example, (1,1,1,5)(1,1,1,5) is not a rectangle as it does not satisfy u<du<d.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and mm (2≤n,m2≤n,m, n⋅m≤250000n⋅m≤250000).

Each of the nn following lines contains a string of length mm denoting the ii-th row of GG (Gi,j∈{0,1}Gi,j∈{0,1}).

It is guaranteed that the sum of n⋅mn⋅m over all test cases does not exceed 250000250000.
outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output a grid of nn rows and mm columns. On the jj-th column of the ii-th row, you should output:

  • If there exists a rectangle (u,d,l,r)(u,d,l,r) such that u≤i≤du≤i≤d and l≤j≤rl≤j≤r, output the minimum area of any such rectangle;
  • Otherwise, output 00 instead.
noteHtml:
The first test case is explained in the statement.

For the third test case, there are six rectangles that cover at least one cell with minimum area:

  • (1,3,1,2)(1,3,1,2), which has area 66;
  • (1,2,1,3)(1,2,1,3), which has area 66;
  • (3,4,2,3)(3,4,2,3), which has area 44;
  • (2,3,3,4)(2,3,3,4), which has area 44;
  • (3,5,4,5)(3,5,4,5), which has area 66;
  • (4,5,3,5)(4,5,3,5), which has area 66.
